Translation of 楚竹書・柬大王泊旱(en) into English.

p.seg: The great king Jian (of Chu), having exposed himself to dispel the drought (?),
ordered the official in charge of the turtles, Luo, to conduct divination on Da Xia (=one of the turtles? a great river?) (about it).
The king approached (participated in) the divination personally.
The king stood facing the sun,
the king's sweat reached his belt.
The official in charge of the turtles knew
that the king got scorched by the sun and got ill,
and passed over the handle of the canopy to lean over him. (?)
As the regulating official (in charge of sacrifices) knew
of the sickness of the king,
he assisted the official in charge of the turtles
in speeding up the divination (ritual) towards the high mountains and the deep rivers.
The king thereby asked regulating official Gao:
“I feel dry and extremely sick,
and I have been dreaming many times about the high mountains and the deep rivers.
Among the lands I got in Lü,
there are no famous mountains or rivers.
I want to conduct a sacrifice for the state of Chu,
you should decide (?) and divine about it with Da Xia.
If it is verified, we should proceed with the sacrifice.”
The regulating official assented,
decided (?) and divined about it,
and it was verified.
The regulating official reported the charge to the ruler:
“It has already been decided and divined about, and it has been verified.”
The king said:
“If it has been verified,
let’s speed up the sacrifice,
I feel dry and very ill.”
The regulating official replied:
“The state of Chu has a permanent regulation,
how could I dare to diminish (=simplify) the sacrifice?
to simplify the sacrifice due to the person (=personal concern) of the king.”
this has never yet happened
The king entered (the court)
to report to lord An and the regulating official Gao:
“Earlier I acted for my personal convenience (in asking to speed up the sacrifice),
people will laugh at me.”
The overseer of Ling and the regulating official took hold of his words
and reported them to the senior minister:
“You are a wise man and a good elder,
you will redress (this situation) for the lord.”
The senior minister told the regulating official:
“You should enter the court
and report my words to the lord,
and the lord’s dry (sickness) from today will thereby be cured.”
The overseer of Ling and the regulating official [asked]:
“Is there a (hidden) reason (for the lord's sickness)?
We would like to hear about it.”
The senior minister said:
The sovereign is a good lord,
he did (or: will?) not change for his person (=personal reasons) the permanent regulations of the regulating official;
the regulating official is in charge of the ghosts and spirits of the state of Chu,
and did not dare, for the king’s sake,
to change and bring disorder to the permanent regulations of the ghosts and spirits
Now God on High and the ghosts and spirits are extremely lofty and intelligent,
they will necessarily understand this.
The sovereign’s sickness will thereby finish from today.”
The Prime Minister Zi Lin asked the senior minister Zi Zhi:
“Serving in the role of minister
there should also be remonstrations?”
The senior minister answered:
“The sovereign is a good lord,
when a lord is good,
which usage has a dignitary for remonstrations?”
The Prime Minister told the senior minister:
“Yes.
It must be the case that the army has a great defeat,
the state and the main families are in great trouble
and the altars of the land and grain are in danger.”
(or it is the case that) there is a great drought in the state,
and therefore (the lord) must receive advice about the state,
so that a report should be made for the host [=the lord].
The senior minister then told them:
“You are all generals of the Chu state,
if you put up a serious countenance and talk about (this issue) in the court,
how the king’s affairs [...]
The king assented.
[he said that in his dream someone] would beat the drum
and make them wade the river.
The king had this dream three times.
The inner doors where not yet open,
and he told the XX official and the YY official about it:
“Tonight I had a dream like this,
why?”
The XX official and the YY official answered:
“Your majesty should ask the senior minister, the marquis of Jin, about it,
he is the offspring of wise men.”
“[ in my dream someone would always beat the drum
and make them wade the river,
what does it mean?”
The senior minister advanced and answered:
“This is the so called ‘mother of the drought’,
God will command her
to reform those among the rulers of the feudal states which are not able to bring order,
and to punish them by means of the drought.
Now, even without a drought
the common people would migrate
and thereby abandon the state and the main clans.
This is (also) a punishment for the king.”
The king faced up to Heaven and cried,
and weeping told the senior minister:
“I cannot regulate the government
and the common people’s livelihood thereby is severed.”
Afterwards the senior minister withdrew.
(The king then) had the senior minister to return and advance:
“What should I do,
so that the harvest be ripe?”
The senior minister answered:
“If his majesty will repair the suburbs (suburban altars) of Ying,
and the king should not dare to erect the great canopy (thereby not being screened against the sun),
and the XX official and the YY official and the five connected young sons (?) and the favorite ministers should all be attached (=follow him)
and should not dare to hold the ceremonial multicolored fan (thereby also not being screened against the sun).
